author: siladu
content:
I know this _shouldn't_ happen, but...

engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV1 spec does not explicitly say "throw an error if you receive a withdrawals field", so how are other EL clients handling this? 

Have you had to add specific validation into engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV1 to support this or could engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV1 potentially process withdrawals given it was passed valid V2 data?

author: potuz
content: Just checking: gwei for withdrawal amounts, historical summaries and genesis fork version for bls changes right?

author: sproul
content: yep!

author: potuz
content: How are you guys dealing with the first broadcast of changes. I know we haven't decided anything

author: sproul
content:
we're still rejecting until the head is Capella, but should change that

my preferred solution for the adversarial publishing race is still a CLI flag to load an agreed list of address changes, but we also haven't implemented that yet

author: potuz
content: We will ignore before Capella but local changes can be added by a command or a curl to the endpoint before the fork. Currently we will not broadcast these changes but I wanted to merge today when I wake up the PR to broadcast at the fork

author: potuz
content: The thing is the subtlety between head state and wall clock. I'll go with wall clock is after the fork and I'm hoping all clients do this. Head state may happen before, so it's safe that other clients that don't agree on when to start accepting will take our changes, but also it may mean that we will lose the race for inclusion in the pool

author: nishant0
content: we dont need to worry about the head state

author: nishant0
content: since the fork version has been changed to the genesis fork version, it doesn't matter

author: nishant0
content: we can still verify change messages in gossip if the head state is in bellatrix

author: potuz
content: We do need to worry, the issue here is when do clients will start accepting these changes into their pools instead of ignoring

author: nishant0
content: why would they ignore them ?

author: potuz
content: Because that's what the spec says

author: potuz
content: There's still discussion as to what to do, I'm on the camp that we should ignore and accept only at wall clock at The fork. And also that we should broadcast all local changes at the fork (again wall clock)

author: nishant0
content:
```
Ignore signed_bls_to_execution_change message before CAPELLA_FORK_EPOCH
```
This is fine

author: nishant0
content: it just means if your local clock is before the fork epoch you ignore it

author: potuz
content: Yes

author: potuz
content: But if clients decide to implement head state instead of wall clock, there may be a subtlety with optimizations that advance and process the slot before the wall clock

author: potuz
content: And if clients also decide to broadcast right after Epoch transition instead of wall clock, then those clients will fill their pools before we broadcast our local changes. So I think it's better to agree on one event to all behave the same way

author: nishant0
content: I think the spec is clear here in that it is referring to wall clock, rather than the head state

author: nishant0
content: If clients are broadcasting, then following the wall clock makes much more sense.

author: potuz
content: I agree, just want to make sure we're all on the same page

author: g11tech
content: any transaction regarding limt/init metercode minted by ethereumjs will fail: the fix is here https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/pull/2486

author: g11tech
content: but its still wip and may take a day or two to merge

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yep it was proposed by ethereumjs, so we can just ignore it

author: potuz
content: <@360491619402776577> if you'll be testing these transactions, isn't it better to just stop the ethereumjs validators until that fix merges?

author: g11tech
content: the problem is while blockproduction and not block processing, so when the transaction is included by some other node, ethereumjs will also correctly process the correct block and follow the chain

author: potuz
content: specially if it's only production, we can keep the nodes running, just not the proposers

author: potuz
content: So that these transactions will be mined and tested

author: g11tech
content: well its about a particular eip of transaction (limit/init metercode), but doen't actually hurt the chain as the bad block gets reorged out

author: potuz
content: yeah, fair point. As long as those transactions are included in the next blocks it's good

author: g11tech
content: yes they get included in next block üëç (from the debugging i did)

author: barnabasbusa
content: Instead of waiting endlessly for approvals, I would propose that a team would need to actively disagree if they don't like something.

author: parithosh
content: Well the PR is 4 days old with a weekend in between. I'd say merging it without allowing for everyone to have a look would also be unreasonable üòÖ But yea, it would help if client teams can explicitly approve this specific PR as soon as possible so it isnt a blocker.

author: ralexstokes
content:
right, to be clear i'm not attached to any particular process ("100% approval on this PR") but i do think it is important to stick to some (semi-)formalized governance process as this is a constant battle we fight to make sure the protocol cannot be captured and our values do not erode

with this in mind, i'm following what i understood to be the last outcome of a credibly-recognized decision point (ACDC) where we said we would make a decision _at the latest_ on the next ACDE call

if we can gain asynchronous consensus _sooner than that_ i am all for it! but as we can see, asynchronous consensus is expensive and i dont have time to chase down a long tail of PRs across many clients; i'd rather move a little more slowly than steamroll over a valid but conflicting opinion

author: ralexstokes
content: ok, so i did go chase all the code down and it looks like the 10 clients i'll count have all implemented this in some fashion, i'll go merge the PRs

author: barnabasbusa
content: Wouldn't it be enough for you if a client team mentions your PR in their PR? That way all in one place you could see that all client teams are already have something implemented, and if they would have some opposition, they wouldn't even open a pr regarding it.

author: parithosh
content: A team could potentially start prototyping something in a PR and then realize something is wrong with the proposal. So I'd say a merged PR is probably the sign you're looking for.

author: barnabasbusa
content: having a PR merged before the spec is merged is kind of a chicken and egg problem tho.

author: ralexstokes
content: i think there are many ways to signal support and they are all valid; i also wasn't convinced this was the case for this one change until i did a little digging myself which i am making time for bc i think this is important üôÇ

author: barnabasbusa
content: Thanks for taking the time.

author: barnabasbusa
content: We need some better way for client teams to voice their opinion about certain PRs.

author: barnabasbusa
content: some voting site or something, where a team can quickly say yes or no.

author: barnabasbusa
content: I know github...

author: ralexstokes
content: well we have ACD{C,E} for this

author: ralexstokes
content: i agree the process can be improved, possibly by a lot; but it is the current structure we have today so we have to make do

author: barnabasbusa
content: I don't think that is frequent enough tbh.

author: barnabasbusa
content: Looks like we will still be on track to have a devnet 3 launch tomorrow morning. LH/Lodestar already have implementation merged. Teku/Prysm/nimbus should have something merged very soon. EL side, erigon/geth are ready to go, with nethermind and besu, and ethereumjs almost ready. Over tonight, pls leave a comment if you are one of the teams that hasn't got their docker image published, and let me know if you are ready to go. https://notes.ethereum.org/@bbusa/withdrawal-devnet-3
